articles.title: How Dropbox Reduced the Size of Its JavaScript Bundles by 33%
articles.description: The folks at Dropbox realize that when you‚Äôre operating at scale, small annoyances and delays add up, and their web perf team narrowed down some of Dropbox‚Äôs perf issues to their module bundling process.
articles.author: Nadeem and Hong (Dropbox)

articles.title: htmx is Part of the GitHub Accelerator
articles.description: htmx is a perfect example of a library that isn‚Äôt brand new, but one that becomes popular once the time is right. Its success is only continuing following acceptance into the first class of GitHub‚Äôs open-source Accelerator initiative, an opportunity that will enable the development of htmx 2.0. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Big Sky Software

articles.title: You Don't (May Not) Need Lodash or Underscore
articles.description: Inspired by the popular You Might Not Need jQuery, this extensive document provides pure JavaScript alternatives to almost 100 different functions as you‚Äôd find in popular utility libraries like Lodash.
articles.author: You Don't Need

articles.title: Discover three.js: A Complete Guide to Creating 3D Web Experiences
articles.description: The breadth of the content on offer here had me looking for the price, but it‚Äôs all online and free. There‚Äôs a lot to dig through here if you want to get started (or just get better) at using three.js. If you‚Äôre already familiar with three.js, you may enjoy the three.js tips and tricks page.
articles.author: Lewy Blue

articles.title: JSX Without React
articles.description: Exploring a new tool called NakedJSX that will allow you to render JSX without the need for the full React framework.
articles.author: Chris Coyier

articles.title: You‚Äôve Got Options for Removing Event Listeners
articles.description: Reviewing some of the most common approaches available to remove event listeners in JavaScript.
articles.author: Alex MacArthur

articles.title: Prepare Your Firefox Desktop Extension for the Upcoming Android¬†Release
articles.description: ‚ÄúFirefox will become the only major Android browser to support an open extension ecosystem.‚Äù
articles.author: Scott DeVaney (Mozilla)

articles.title: Croner 7.0: Cron for JavaScript and TypeScript
articles.description: Trigger functions upon the schedule of your choice using the classic cron syntax. Works in Node, Deno, Bun and the browser, across time zones, offers error handling and overrun protection, and more. There‚Äôs an live demo on JSFiddle. v7.0 adds support for specifying the n-th weekday.
articles.author: Hexagon

articles.title: Linkify 4.1: Link Up URLs, Email Addresses, and More in Plain Text
articles.description: Given some plain text containing things like links and emails, Linkify will generate the correct code to display it on the Web. Not just URLs or emails, but hashtags, @mentions, IP addresses, and more ‚Äì see the homepage for examples. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Hypercontext

articles.title: deno_python: Python Interpreter Bindings for Deno
articles.description: A seamless Deno-Python integration via the Python/C API. The latest release supports installing and importing pip packages. This feature has been described as ‚Äúslightly cursed‚Äù but it‚Äôs certainly interesting.
articles.author: Denosaurs

articles.title: Tagger: A Zero Dependency, Vanilla JavaScript Tagging Library
articles.description: You can play with a live demo here.
articles.author: Jakub T. Jankiewicz

articles.title: Over 100 Algorithms and Data Structures Demonstrated in JS
articles.description: Examples of many common algorithms (e.g. bit manipulation, Pascal‚Äôs triangle, Hamming distance) and data structures (e.g. linked lists, tries, graphs) with explanations. Available in other languages too like Chinese, Korean, French, and Spanish.
articles.author: Oleksii Trekhleb et al.

articles.title: Proto Tree: A Way to Observe the JS Prototype Chain
articles.description: Gal explains the motivation for this tool in üê¶ this Twitter thread.
articles.author: Gal Weizman

articles.title: Barba.js: For Smooth Visual Transitions Between Pages
articles.description: You certainly can‚Äôt say the project‚Äôs homepage doesn‚Äôt show off all of its features. For such a dramatic set of effects, things feel smooth and surprisingly nice üòÅ GitHub repo.
articles.author: De Rosa, Michel, et al.

articles.title: Stritch: A JavaScript Barcode Scanning Library
articles.description: It‚Äôs a commercial library, but featureful and well presented with support for a variety of 1D and 2D barcode types.
articles.author: Pixelverse LLC

articles.title: #Script: A JS-Inspired Scripting Language for .NET
articles.description: An embeddable scripting language mostly targeting template use cases. It can also be used in a Lisp style.
articles.author: ServiceStack

articles.title: ngraph.path: Path Finding Through Graphs
articles.description: There‚Äôs a live demo if you want to see how it tackles the road network of several global cities.
articles.author: Andrei Kashcha

articles.description: It's still a few weeks away, but we're told "Bun 1.0 is almost here" and there's üìÖ a live presentation by Bun's creator, Jarred Sumner, on September 7 you can sign up for now.

If you like to keep up with other languages than JavaScript, renowned C++ expert Herb Sutter recently ‚ñ∂Ô∏è gave a fantastic talk about modernizing and improving C++ more quickly by creating a Typescript-esque superset with better abstractions and features.
üïπ React Jam was a React-oriented gamejam that took place last week and here are the winning games.
üëæ Talking of gaming, the annual js13kGames JS coding competition has just started. You can join in the fun, though, as it doesn't end till September 13.
Robin Wieruch shared his 10 Web development trends in 2023 back in January ‚Äì how are they shaping up so far? As Larry David might say.. pretty, pretty good.
In "The ‚ÄúSkeleton Squad‚Äù is now targeting NPM", the team at Socket take a look at how a group is attacking the npm package ecosystem.

articles.title: How to Make Lists Accessible
articles.description: This guide covers why accessible lists and tables matter, how to make them accessible, and how to fix inaccessible lists and tables.
articles.author: Whitney Lewis

articles.title: Testing Your Refresh Rate with a CSS Trick?
articles.description: This is a fascinating way to show users the refresh rate of their screen by spinning a specially designed zoetrope-like disc graphic at speed. As it spins, the numbers representing the viewer‚Äôs refresh rate should remain visually stable unlike surrounding numbers.
articles.author: Luna on cohost

articles.title: Alt Text Hall of Fame: Celebrating Well-Written Image Descriptions
articles.description: Why is alt text important? This site goes some way to explain via a showcase of good examples.
articles.author: Stefan Bohacek

articles.title: 'It‚Äôs Time to End Damaging Website Design Practices That May Harm Your Users'
articles.description: The UK‚Äôs Information Commissioner‚Äôs Office (ICO) along with the Competition & Markets Authority (CMA) have released a joint paper on harmful design in digital markets. PDF here.
articles.author: Almond and Hayter

articles.title: Four New CSS Features for Smooth Entry and Exit Animations
articles.description: This is a solid look at new capabilities found in Chrome 116 and 117 that enable smooth animations and transitions for discrete properties. Lots of good visuals and code examples.
articles.author: Kravets and Arhar (Chrome Developers)

articles.title: An Overview of CSS Sizing Units
articles.description: Explore the four broad categories of CSS sizing units, how to apply them in your layouts, and how to choose the best ones in each scenario.
articles.author: Tiffany Brown

articles.title: Chrome Extension Maker Tells of Pressure to Sell Out
articles.description: A popular Chrome extension creator has received more than 130 solicitations to monetize their browser tool over the years. ‚ÄúAnyone with sizable audience in this surveillance economy is invited to stuff their add-ons with tracking and ads‚Äù.
articles.author: Thomas Claburn interview

articles.title: A Fancy Hover Effect For Your Avatar
articles.description: A quick look at how to create a neat ‚Äòpop out‚Äô hover effect using CSS.
articles.author: Temani Afif

articles.title: User-Adaptive Interfaces with AccentColor
articles.description: A quick tip on respecting user preferences for form controls via the new AccentColor keyword.
articles.author: Ollie Williams

articles.title: Bringing Sharp to WebAssembly and WebContainers
articles.description: A look at how it‚Äôs possible to bring Sharp, a popular Node.js image manipulation module, into the browser. This is futuristic stuff.
articles.author: Ingvar Stepanyan

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Drawing a Cute Character with CSS
articles.description: In roughly ten minutes Alvaro shows us how to create an Anime-style character using just CSS. The effort took around an hour and twenty minutes, but we get to watch along via a time-lapse.
articles.author: Alvaro Montoro

articles.title: Prepare Your Firefox Desktop Extension for the Upcoming Android Release
articles.description: ‚ÄúFirefox will become the only major Android browser to support an open extension ecosystem.‚Äù
articles.author: Scott DeVaney (Mozilla)

articles.title: Introducing the Energy Saving Concept of Lower Carbon¬†Graphics
articles.description: This article is focused specifically on TVs and saving energy based on what colors are shown on screen, but the findings may be of interest to us frontend devs ‚Äî who often make a lot of decisions about what ends up on many a variety of screen.
articles.author: Colin Warhurst (BBC)

articles.title: OddContrast
articles.description: A straightforward color contrast checker with Oklch, Oklab, Display P3, and more ‚Äì results all meet WCAG 2 accessibility standards.
articles.author: OddBird

articles.title: Iconbuddy: An Icon Search Engine with 180K+ Open Source Icons
articles.description: You can search for an icon collection or individual icon (SVG, PNG, etc.), or create an account to manage your collections. Any icon you select can be edited and customized before exporting.
articles.author: Iconbuddy

articles.title: Primo
articles.description: A visual CMS that generates a static site. Primo itself is a SvelteKit application using Supabase as a backend.
articles.author: Primo

articles.title: twentyhq/favicon: Fetch Favicons From Any Website
articles.description: It‚Äôs an API that lets you grab a website‚Äôs favicon/logo via a URL like the following for Apple's site: https:‚Äã//favicon.twenty‚Äã.com/apple.com
articles.author: Twenty

articles.title: LangUI: An Library of 60+ Tailwind Components for AI and GPT¬†Projects
articles.description: The components are fairly generic, so not necessarily restricted to use for AI/GPT, as advertised. But they‚Äôre nice and include dark and light modes, which you can try out live in the docs.
articles.author: Ahmad Bilal

articles.title: Flying Toasters Screensaver ‚Äî After Dark in CSS
articles.description: ..remember this? It‚Äôs a CSS recreation of the iconic Flying Toasters screensaver from the After Dark collection (which was sold on CD in the late 80s / early 90s). Bryan has been busy recreating a handful of them - a lovely little blast of nostalgia.
articles.author: Bryan Braun

articles.description: Here's a look over what's new in the DevTools of Chrome 116, including a visual way to configure linear timings for transitions in the Easing Editor.
Could browsers be required by law to stop you from visiting infringing sites?
Chris Siebenmann notes how browsers "barely care what HTTP status code your web pages are served with".
Chad Stewart is hosting a free workshop next week on architecture and tooling for your next frontend project.
Hop in the internet time machine and see what Apple, Google and the Amazon websites looked like in 1999.
